chapter.title: Reference
chapter.para: This chapter documents the drivers and options that can be used in the configuration file. For details on how to use syslog-ng, see .

section.title: internal()
section.para: All messages generated internally by syslog-ng use this special source. To collect warnings, errors and notices from syslog-ng itself, include this source in one of your source statements.

note.para: Internal messages always use the local timezone of the host.

section.para: This driver does not have any parameters.

section.title: file()
section.para: Collects log messages from plain-text files. The file driver has a single required parameter specifying the file to open.

note.para: If the message does not have a proper syslog header, syslog-ng treats messages received from files as sent by the kern facility. Use the default-facility and default-priority options in the source definition to assign a different facility if needed.

section.para: The file() driver has the following options:

simplesect.title: file
simplesect.para: Description: The file to read messages from. Note that only syslog-ng PE supports wildcards in the filename (but not in the pathname). To monitor the subdirectories as well, use the recursive option.

simplesect.title: recursive
simplesect.para: Description: When enabled, syslog-ng PE monitors every subdirectory of the directory set in the path of the file parameter, and reads log messages from files with the set filename. The recursive option can be used together with wildcards in the filename.

section.title: pipe()
section.para: The pipe driver opens a named pipe with the specified name and listens for messages. It is used as the native message delivery protocol on HP-UX.
The pipe driver has a single required parameter, specifying the filename of the pipe to open.

note.para: As of syslog-ng Open Source Edition 3.0.2, pipes are created automatically. In earlier versions, you had to create the pipe using the mkfifo(1) command.

section.para: The pipe driver has the following options:

simplesect.title: pipe
simplesect.para: Description: The filename of the pipe to read messages from.

section.title: program()
section.para: The program driver starts an external application and reads messages from the standard output (stdout) of the application. It is mainly useful to receive log messages from daemons that accept incoming messages and convert them to log messages.
The program driver has a single required parameter, specifying the name of the application to start.

note.para: The program is restarted automatically if it exits.

section.para: The program driver has the following options:

simplesect.title: program
simplesect.para: Description: The name of the application to start and read messages from.

section.title: sun-streams() driver
section.para: Solaris uses its STREAMS framework to send messages to the syslogd process.

Newer versions of Solaris (2.5.1 and above), use a new IPC in addition to STREAMS, called door to confirm the delivery of a message. The syslog-ng application supports this new IPC mechanism via the door() option (see below).

note.para: The sun-streams() driver must be enabled when the syslog-ng application is compiled (see ./configure --help).

section.para: The sun-streams() driver has a single required argument specifying the STREAMS device to open, and the door() option.

simplesect.title: door()
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the filename of a door to open, needed on Solaris above 2.5.1.

section.title: syslog()
section.para: This driver enables to receive messages from the network using the new standard syslog protocol and message format (see for details about the protocol). UDP, TCP, and TLS-encrypted TCP can all be used to transport the messages.

simplesect.title: transport
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the protocol used to receive messages from the source.

section.title: tcp(), tcp6(), udp() and udp6()
section.para: The tcp(), tcp6(), udp(), udp6() drivers can receive messages from the network using the TCP and UDP networking protocols. The tcp6() and udp6() drivers use the IPv6 network protocol, while tcp() and udp() use IPv4.

The tcp() and udp() drivers do not have any required parameters. By default they bind to 0.0.0.0:514, which means that syslog-ng will listen on all available interfaces, port 514. To limit accepted connections to only one interface, use the localip() parameter as described below.

note.para: The tcp port 514 is reserved for use with rshell, so select a different port if syslog-ng and rshell is used at the same time.

section.para: If you specify a multicast bind address to udp() and udp6(), syslog-ng will automatically join the necessary multicast group. TCP does not support multicasting.
The syslog-ng application supports TLS (Transport Layer Security, also known as SSL) for the tcp() and tcp6() drivers. See the TLS-specific options below and for details.
The following options are valid for tcp(), tcp6(), udp(), and udp6() drivers:

section.title: unix-stream() and unix-dgram()
section.para: These two drivers behave similarly: they open an AF_UNIX socket and start listening on it for messages.
Both unix-stream and unix-dgram have a single required argument, specifying the filename of the socket to create.
The following options can be specified for these divers:

simplesect.title: group()
simplesect.para: Description: Set the gid of the socket.

simplesect.title: keep-alive()
simplesect.para: Description: Selects whether to keep connections open when syslog-ng is restarted; cannot be used with unix-dgram().

simplesect.title: max-connections()
simplesect.para: Description: Limits the number of simultaneously open connections. Cannot be used with unix-dgram().

simplesect.title: owner()
simplesect.para: Description: Set the uid of the socket.

simplesect.title: perm()
simplesect.para: Description: Set the permission mask. For octal numbers prefix the number with '0', for example: use 0755 for rwxr-xr-x.

example.title: Using the unix-stream() and unix-dgram() drivers

section.title: Destination drivers
section.para: Destination drivers output log messages to somewhere outside syslog-ng for example to a file or a network socket.

section.title: file()
section.para: The file driver outputs messages to the specified text file, or to a set of files.
The destination filename may include macros which get expanded when the message is written, thus a simple file() driver may create several files. For more information on available macros see .
The file() destination has the following options:

simplesect.title: create_dirs()
simplesect.para: Description: Enable creating non-existing directories.

simplesect.title: dir_group()
simplesect.para: Description: The group of directories created by syslog-ng.

simplesect.title: dir_owner()
simplesect.para: Description: The owner of directories created by syslog-ng.

simplesect.title: dir_perm()
simplesect.para: Description: The permission mask of directories created by syslog-ng. Log directories are only created if a file after macro expansion refers to a non-existing directory, and directory creation is enabled (see the create_dirs() option below). For octal numbers prefix the number with 0, for example use 0755 for rwxr-xr-x.

simplesect.title: group()
simplesect.para: Description: Set the group of the created file to the one specified.

simplesect.title: overwrite_if_older()
simplesect.para: Description: If set to a value higher than 0, syslog-ng checks when the file was last modified before starting to write into the file. If the file is older than the specified amount of time (in seconds), then syslog-ng removes the existing file and opens a new file with the same name. In combination with for example the $WEEKDAY macro, this can be used for simple log rotation, in case not all history has to be kept. (Note that in this weekly log rotation example if its Monday 00:01, then the file from last Monday is not seven days old, because it was probably last modified shortly before 23:59 last Monday, so it is actually not even six days old. So in this case, set the overwrite_if_older() parameter to a-bit-less-than-six-days, for example, to 518000 seconds.

simplesect.title: owner()
simplesect.para: Description: Set the owner of the created file to the one specified.

simplesect.title: perm()
simplesect.para: Description: The permission mask of the file if it is created by syslog-ng. For octal numbers prefix the number with 0, for example use 0755 for rwxr-xr-x.

example.title: Using the file() driver with macros in the file name and a template for the message

section.title: pipe()
section.para: This driver sends messages to a named pipe like /dev/xconsole.
The pipe driver has a single required parameter, specifying the filename of the pipe to open. The filename can include macros.

warning.para: As of syslog-ng Open Source Edition 3.0.2, pipes are created automatically. In earlier versions, you had to create the pipe using the mkfifo(1) command.

section.para: The pipe() destination has the following options:

simplesect.title: group()
simplesect.para: Description: Set the group of the pipe to the one specified.

simplesect.title: owner()
simplesect.para: Description: Set the owner of the pipe to the one specified.

simplesect.title: perm()
simplesect.para: Description:The permission mask of the pipe. For octal numbers prefix the number with '0', for example: use 0755 for rwxr-xr-x.

section.title: program()
section.para: This driver starts an external application or script and sends the log messages to its standard input (stdin).
The program() driver has a single required parameter, specifying a program name to start.
The program() destination has the following options:

section.title: sql()
section.para: This driver sends messages into an SQL database. The sql() driver has the following required parameters: type, database, table, columns, values.
The sql() destination has the following options:

simplesect.title: columns
simplesect.para: Description: Name of the columns storing the data in fieldname [dbtype] format. The [dbtype] parameter is optional, and specifies the type of the field. By default, syslog-ng creates text columns. Note that not every database engine can index text fields.

simplesect.title: database
simplesect.para: Description: Name of the database that stores the logs.

simplesect.title: host
simplesect.para: Description: Hostname of the database server. Note that Oracle destinations do not use this parameter, but retrieve the hostname from the /etc/tnsnames.ora file.

simplesect.title: indexes
simplesect.para: Description: The list of columns that are indexed by the database to speed up searching. To disable indexing for the destination, include the empty indexes() parameter in the destination, simply omitting the indexes parameter will cause syslog-ng to request indexing on the default columns.

simplesect.title: null
simplesect.para: Description: If the content of a column matches the string specified in the null() parameter, the contents of the column will be replaced with an SQL NULL value. If unset (by default), the option does not match on any string. See the for details.

simplesect.title: password
simplesect.para: Description: Password of the database user.

simplesect.title: table
simplesect.para: Description: Name of the database table to use (can include macros). When using macros, note that some databases limit the length of table names.

simplesect.title: type

row.entry: mssql, mysql, oracle, pgsql, or sqlite3

simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the type of the database, i.e., the DBI database driver to use. Use the mssql option to send logs to an MSSQL database. See the examples of the databases on the following sections for details.

simplesect.title: username
simplesect.para: Description: Name of the database user.

simplesect.title: values
simplesect.para: Description:The parts of the message to store in the fields specified in the columns parameter.

note.para: If you specify host="localhost", syslog-ng will use a socket to connect to the local database server. Use host="127.0.0.1" to force TCP communication between syslog-ng and the local database server.
To specify the socket to use, set and export the MYSQL_UNIX_PORT environment variable, for example MYSQL_UNIX_PORT=/var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock; export MYSQL_UNIX_PORT.

section.title: syslog()
section.para: The syslog() driver sends messages to a remote host (for example a syslog-ng server or relay) on the local intranet or internet using the new standard syslog protocol developed by IETF (see for details about the protocol). The protocol supports sending messages using the UDP, TCP, or the encrypted TLS networking protocols.
The required arguments of the driver are the address of the destination host (where messages should be sent) and the transport method (networking protocol).
The udp transport method automatically sends multicast packets if a multicast destination address is specified. The tcp and tls methods do not support multicasting.
These destinations have the following options:

simplesect.title: port() or destport()
simplesect.para: Description: The port number to connect to. Note that the default port numbers used by syslog-ng do not comply with the latest RFC which was published after the release of syslog-ng 3.0.2, therefore the default port numbers will change in the future releases.

simplesect.title: transport
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the protocol used to receive messages from the source.

example.title: Using the syslog() driver
example.synopsis: destination d_tcp { syslog(ip("10.1.2.3") transport("tcp") port(1999) localport(999)); };
example.para: If name resolution is configured, the hostname of the target server can be used as well.
example.synopsis: destination d_tcp { syslog(ip("target_host") transport("tcp") port(1999) localport(999)); };
example.para: Send the log messages using TLS encryption and use mutual authentication. See for details on the encryption and authentication options.

section.title: tcp(), tcp6(), udp(), and udp6()
section.para: This driver sends messages to another host on the local intranet or internet using the UDP or TCP protocol. The tcp6() and udp6() drivers use the IPv6 network protocol.

Both drivers have a single required argument specifying the destination host address, where messages should be sent, and several optional parameters. Note that this differs from source drivers, where local bind address is implied, and none of the parameters are required.
The udp() and udp6() drivers automatically send multicast packets if a multicast destination address is specified. The tcp() and tcp6() drivers do not support multicasting.

example.title: Using the tcp() driver
example.para: If name resolution is configured, the hostname of the target server can be used as well.

section.para: These destinations have the following options:

section.title: unix-stream() & unix-dgram()
section.para: These drivers send messages to a unix socket in either SOCK_STREAM or SOCK_DGRAM mode.
Both drivers have a single required argument specifying the name of the socket to connect to.
The unix-stream() and unix-dgram() destinations have the following options:

section.title: usertty()
section.para: This driver writes messages to the terminal of a logged-in user.
The usertty() driver has a single required argument, specifying a username who should receive a copy of matching messages. Use the asterisk * to specify every user currently logged in to the system.
The usertty() does not have any further options nor does it support templates.

section.title: Global options
section.para: The following options can be specified in the options statement, as described in .

simplesect.title: bad_hostname()
simplesect.para: Description: A regexp containing hostnames which should not be handled as hostnames.

simplesect.title: chain_hostnames()
simplesect.para: Description: Enable or disable the chained hostname format.

simplesect.title: check_hostname()
simplesect.para: Description: Enable or disable checking whether the hostname contains valid characters.

simplesect.title: create_dirs()
simplesect.para: Description: Enable or disable directory creation for destination files.

simplesect.title: dir_group()
simplesect.para: Description: The default group for newly created directories.

simplesect.title: dir_owner()
simplesect.para: Description: The default owner of newly created directories.

simplesect.title: dir_perm()
simplesect.para: Description: The default permission for newly created directories.

simplesect.title: dns_cache()
simplesect.para: Description: Enable or disable DNS cache usage.

simplesect.title: dns_cache_expire()
simplesect.para: Description: Number of seconds while a successful lookup is cached.

simplesect.title: dns_cache_expire_failed()
simplesect.para: Description: Number of seconds while a failed lookup is cached.

simplesect.title: dns_cache_hosts()
simplesect.para: Description: Name of a file in /etc/hosts format that contains static IP->hostname mappings. Use this option to resolve hostnames locally without using a DNS. Note that any change to this file triggers a reload in syslog-ng and is instantaneous.

simplesect.title: dns_cache_size()
simplesect.para: Description: Number of hostnames in the DNS cache.

simplesect.title: flush_lines()
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies how many lines are flushed to a destination at a time. Syslog-ng waits for this number of lines to accumulate and sends them off in a single batch. Setting this number high increases throughput as fully filled frames are sent to the network, but also increases message latency. The latency can be limited by the use of the flush_timeout option.

simplesect.title: flush_timeout()
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the time syslog-ng waits for lines to accumulate in its output buffer. See the flush_lines() option for more information.

simplesect.title: group()
simplesect.para: Description: The default group of output files. By default, syslog-ng changes the privileges of accessed files (for example /dev/null) to root.root 0600. To disable modifying privileges, use this option with the -1 value.

simplesect.title: log_fifo_size()
simplesect.para: Description: The number of lines fitting to the output queue. Note that it is not possible to set this option lower than 1000.

simplesect.title: log_msg_size()
simplesect.para: Description: Maximum length of a message in bytes.

simplesect.title: normalize_hostnames()
simplesect.para: Description: Normalize hostnames, which currently translates to converting them to lower case. (requires 1.9.9)

simplesect.title: owner()
simplesect.para: Description: The default owner of output files. By default, syslog-ng changes the privileges of accessed files (for example /dev/null) to root.root 0600. To disable modifying privileges, use this option with the -1 value.

simplesect.title: mark()
simplesect.para: Description: An alias for the obsolete mark_freq() option, retained for compatibility with syslog-ng version 1.6.x.

simplesect.title: mark_freq()
simplesect.para: Description: The number of seconds between two MARK messages. MARK messages are generated when there was no message traffic to inform the receiver that the connection is still alive. Note that only local messages postpone the sending of the MARK message, relayed messages do not. If set to zero (0), no MARK messages are sent.

simplesect.title: perm()
simplesect.para: Description: The default permission for output files. By default, syslog-ng changes the privileges of accessed files (for example /dev/null) to root.root 0600. To disable modifying privileges, use this option with the -1 value.

simplesect.title: recv_time_zone()
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the time zone associated with the incoming messages, if not specified otherwise in the message or in the source driver. See also and for details.

simplesect.title: send_time_zone()
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the time zone associated with the messages sent by syslog-ng, if not specified otherwise in the message or in the destination driver. See for details.

simplesect.title: stats_freq()
simplesect.para: Description: The period between two STATS messages in seconds. STATS are log messages sent by syslog-ng, containing statistics about dropped log messages. Set to 0 to disable the STATS messages.

simplesect.title: stats_level()
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the detail of statistics syslog-ng collects about the processed messages.

listitem.para: Level 0 collects only statistics about the sources and destinations
Level 1 contains details about the different connections and log files, but has a slight memory overhead
Level 2 contains detailed statistics based on the hostname.
Level 3 contains detailed statistics based on various message parameters like facility, severity, or tags.

simplesect.para: Note that level 2 and 3 increase the memory requirements and CPU load.

simplesect.title: sync() or sync_freq() (DEPRECATED)
simplesect.para: Description: Obsolete aliases for flush_lines()

simplesect.title: time_reap()
simplesect.para: Description: The time to wait in seconds before an idle destination file is closed.

simplesect.title: time_reopen()
simplesect.para: Description: The time to wait in seconds before a dead connection is reestablished.

simplesect.title: time_sleep()
simplesect.para: Description: The time to wait in milliseconds between each invocation of the poll() iteration.

simplesect.title: ts_format()
simplesect.para: Description: Specifies the timestamp format used when syslog-ng itself formats a timestamp and nothing else specifies a format (for example: STAMP macros, internal messages, messages without original timestamps). See also .

simplesect.title: use_time_recvd() (DEPRECATED)
simplesect.para: Description: This option controls how the time related macros are expanded in filename and content templates. If set to yes, then the non-prefixed versions of the time related macros (for example: HOUR instead of R_HOUR and S_HOUR) refer to the time when the message was received, otherwise it refers to the timestamp which is in the message.

note.para: The timestamps in the messages are generated by the originating host and might not be accurate.

simplesect.para: This option is deprecated as many users assumed that it controls the timestamp as it is written to logfiles/destinations, which is not the case. To change how messages are formatted, specify a content-template referring to the appropriate prefixed (S_ or R_) time macro.
